case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v. Ashok Motors Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1989 of 1969 filed by Commissioner of Income-tax Madras.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1989 of 1969. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated Februa

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from judgment and order dated February 8, 1968 of Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 93 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1989 of 1969. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated February 8, 1968 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 93 of 1964.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras appealing against Madras High Court decision in Reference under s. 66(2) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Swaminathan, D. P. Mohanthy and S. Gopalakrishnan, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HEDGE, J. The Commissioner of Income-tax Madras is appealing against the decision of the Madras High Court in a Reference under s. 66 (2)  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  after obtaining certificate of fitness from the High Court.

facts.text: Payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- made by respondent assessee (company) for termination of managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: The question before the authorities under the Act was whether the payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- made by the respondent assessee which will hereinafter be referred to as the companypany for the termination of managing agency is an allowable deduction in companyputing the total income of the companypany for 1956-57.

facts.text: Claim for deduction of Rs. 2,50,000/- as allowable in computing total income for 1956-57 rejected by Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer as well as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim of the Company that it was a Revenue expenditure but the Tribunal in appeal upheld the companytention of the Company Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal, the Commissioner, demanded a case to be stated for obtaining the opinion of the High Court on the question Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- made for the termination of Managing Agency is an allowable deduction in companyputing the total income of the assessee companypany for 1956-57.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld company's contention that payment is revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer as well as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim of the Company that it was a Revenue expenditure but the Tribunal in appeal upheld the companytention of the Company

facts.text: Commissioner demanded case stated for High Court opinion on allowability of Rs. 2,50,000/- deduction.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal, the Commissioner, demanded a case to be stated for obtaining the opinion of the High Court on the question Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- made for the termination of Managing Agency is an allowable deduction in companyputing the total income of the assessee companypany for 1956-57. The Tribunal refused to state the case taking the view that its findings are findings of fact.

facts.text: Tribunal refused to state case, viewing findings as facts.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal refused to state the case taking the view that its findings are findings of fact. Thereafter the Commissioner moved the High Court under s. 66 (2)  and at the instance of the High Court, the Tribunal stated the case and submitted the aforementioned question of law to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court answered question in affirmative, in favour of company.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court answered that question in the affirmative and in favour of the Company. Let us number have a look at the facts. The assessee was a public Limited Co., originally known as Ashok Motors Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee is public limited company, originally Ashok Motors Ltd., incorporated on September 7, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Let us number have a look at the facts. The assessee was a public Limited Co., originally known as Ashok Motors Ltd. It was incorporated on September 7, 1948. The Articles of Association of the Company authorised it to carry on various businesses, such as manufacturers, assemblers, dealers, hirers, repairers of motorcars, motorcycles, motor buses, lorries, trucks etc.

facts.text: Company appointed Car Builders Limited as managing agents under agreement dated October 18, 1948 for 14 years.

anchor.surface_text: The Company appointed Car Builders Limited, as their manag- ing agents under an agreement dated October 18, 1948 for a term of 14 years from the date of its registration.

facts.text: Managing agents paid Rs. 2,000/- per month office allowance and 10% annual profits, minimum Rs. 18,000/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The managing agents were to be paid at the rate of Rs. 2,000/- per mensem as office allowance and 10 per cent of the annual profits with a minimum of Rs. 18,000 per annum in case of inadequacy or absence of profits.

facts.text: Company's initial business: assembly and sale of Austin cars and Leyland Trucks.

anchor.surface_text: Initially the business of the Company companysisted in the assembly ,and sale of Austin cars and Leyland Trucks.

facts.text: In 1952, Government of India referred establishing Automobile Industry to Tariff Commission; company submitted memorandum for Leyland Trucks.

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1952, the Government of India referred the question of establishing an Automobile Industry in India to the Tariff Commission. The Company prepared and submitted a companyprehensive memorandum to the Tariff Commission for the manufacture of Leyland Trucks.

facts.text: From April 1954, company ceased assembling Austin Cars and manufactured Leyland Commercial Vehicles per Government instruction.

anchor.surface_text: From April 1954, the Company ceased to assemble Austin Cars in view of the ,Government decision and engaged itself in the manufacture of Leyland Commercial Vehicles.

facts.text: On January 24, 1955, directors reviewed progress with Union Minister for Commerce and Industry present.

anchor.surface_text: The progress of the scheme was reviewed by all the Directors on January 24, 1955 when the Union Minister for Commerce and Industry was also present.

facts.text: Union Minister suggested inviting Leylands for capital up to 40/45 to 50/55% ratio, max half million pounds; company to raise rest in India.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of the discussion, the Union Minister suggested to the Company to invite Leylands to provide capital as and when required till their holding bore to the existing paid up capital in the ratio of 40/45 to 50155 per cent subject to a maximum of half a million pounds. The Company was asked to rise the remaining capital in India.

facts.text: Minister assured Government would arrange capital in India as contingent liability if managing agency abolished.

anchor.surface_text: The Minister is stated to have assured that the Government would arrange for the required capital in India but that responsibility would be in the nature of companytingent liability and that it would accept such a liability only if the Managing Agency is abolished.

facts.text: Directors informed Minister they had steps to terminate managing agents on payment of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The Directors pointed out to the Minister that they had already taken steps to terminate the services of the managing agents on payment of companypensation.

facts.text: On January 29, 1955, agreement terminated managing agency subject to payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- compensation to managing agents.

anchor.surface_text: On January 29, 1955, by means of an agreement between the Company and the managing agents, the managing agency agreement was terminated subject to the companydition that the managing agents were to be paid companypensation in a sum of -Rs. 2,50,000/.

facts.text: Company paid Rs. 2,50,000/- during accounting year ended December 31, 1955, relevant to assessment year 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: The Company paid the said sum during the accounting year ended on December 31, 1955, relevant to the assessment year 1956-57. The Company claimed deduction of the same in its assessment as revenue expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business in the relevant previous year.

facts.text: Company claimed deduction of payment as revenue expenditure wholly and exclusively for business.

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed deduction of the same in its assessment as revenue expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business in the relevant previous year.

facts.text: Company entered agreement with Leyland Motor Limited, UK for manufacturing programme participation.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be mentioned that at about this time the Company entered into an agreement with Leyland Motor Limited, Leyland U.K. for participation of the said companycern with the Company for implementing its manufacturing programme.

facts.text: Tribunal found termination on business considerations; continuance superfluous due to business change.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the Company. terminated the services of the managing agents on business companysiderations, It accepted the plea of the Company that in view of the change in its business activity, the companytinuance of the managing agents became superfluous.

facts.text: Termination saved office allowance and commission liability for current and future years.

anchor.surface_text: These are findings of fact which are number open to question before this Court. There is numberdoubt that as a result of the termination of the services of the managing agents, the Company got rid of its liability to pay office allowance as well as the companymission it was required to pay under the managing agency agreement number only during the accounting year but also for a few years more.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Commissioner moved the High Court under s. 66 2  and at the instance of the High Court, the Tribunal stated the case and submitted the aforementioned question of law to the High Court. anchor.surface_text: On the aforementioned facts, the question arises whether the compensation paid to the managing agents can be considered as an expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the business or whether the same should be considered as a capital expense. There are numerous decisions of this Court., of the High Courts in this country as well as. of the courts in England dealing with the controversy whether an item of expenditure should be considered as a capital expenditure or revenue expenditure. The Act has not defined the expressions capital expenditure and the revenue expenditure. The line that divides revenue expenditure from capital expenditure is often times very thin.

concepts.interpretation: Distinction applied to determine if compensation for termination of managing agency is deductible as revenue expenditure; not defined in Act, relies on judicial tests

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: venue expenditure from capital expenditure is often times very thin. Hence the decisions of companyrts have number been able to give a quietus to the

concepts.unlisted_label: Distinction between Revenue and Capital Expenditure
concepts.unlisted_description: Judicial doctrine to classify expenditure for tax deductibility

anchor.surface_text: A long line of decisions have laid down that when an expenditure is made with a view to bring into existence an asset or an advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade, there is good reason  in the absence of special circumstances leading to opposite conclusion  for treating such an expenditure as property attributable not to revenue but to capital.

concepts.interpretation: Payment did not create asset or enduring benefit; merely avoided recurring liability to pay office allowance and commission, hence revenue not capital

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: er defined the expressions capital expenditure and the revenue expenditure. The line that divides revenue expenditure from capital expenditure is ofte

concepts.unlisted_description: Test to classify expenditure as capital if it brings enduring advantage to trade

arguments.claim: Avoiding recurring business expenditure does not acquire enduring benefit

anchor.surface_text: It will not be correct to say that by avoiding certain business expenditure, the Company can be said to have acquired enduring benefits or acquired any income yielding asset.

arguments.claim: Payment to get rid of servant when expedient is deductible (Noble precedent)

anchor.surface_text: To quote the illustration given by Rowlatt J. in B. W. Noble Limited v. Mitchell, in the ordinary case a payment to get rid of a servant when it is not expedient to keep him in the interest of trade would be a deductible expenditure.

arguments.claim: Payment to remove recurring disadvantage not acquiring enduring advantage (Noble)

anchor.surface_text: A payment made to remove the possibility of a recurring disadvantage cannot be considered as a payment made to acquire an enduring advantage.

holdings.text: These are findings of fact which are not open to question before this Court.

anchor.surface_text: These are findings of fact which are not open to question before this Court. There is no doubt that as a result of the termination of the services of the managing agents, the Company got rid of its liability to pay office allowance as well as the commission it was required to pay under the managing agency agreement not only during the accounting year but also for a few years more.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's determination on business considerations for termination and superfluity of managing agency continuance upheld as pure findings of fact beyond Supreme Court's review scope.

holdings.text: From the facts found, it is clear that the managing agency was terminated on business considerations and as a matter of commercial expediency.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts found,- it is clear that the managing agency was terminated on business considerations and as a matter of commercial expediency. There is no basis for holding that by terminating the managing agency the Company acquired any enduring benefit ,or any income yielding asset.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on accepted factual findings, termination aligns with commercial expediency test as it avoided unnecessary expenditure amid business shift.

holdings.text: There is no basis for holding that by terminating the managing agency the Company acquired any enduring benefit or any income yielding asset.

anchor.surface_text: There is no basis for holding that by terminating the managing agency. the Company acquired any enduring benefit ,or any income yielding asset. It is true that by terminating the services of the managing agents, the Company not only saved the expense that it would have had to incur in the relevant previous year but also for few more years to come.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of enduring benefit test to facts shows no asset or lasting advantage created, merely relief from recurring payments.

holdings.text: It will not be correct to say that by avoiding certain business expenditure, the Company can be said to have acquired enduring benefits or acquired any income yielding asset.

anchor.surface_text: It will not be correct to say that by avoiding certain business expenditure, the Company can be said to have acquired enduring benefits or acquired any income yielding asset. Mitchell, in the ordinary case a payment to get rid of a servant when it is not expedient to keep him in the interest of trade would be a deductible expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejecting revenue argument; saving recurring costs does not equate to acquiring capital advantage under enduring benefit doctrine.

holdings.text: It is obvious from the facts set out earlier that the compensation paid for termination of the services of the managing agents was a payment made with a view to save business expenditure in the relevant accounting year as well as for a few more years.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the facts set out earlier that the compensation paid for termination of the services of the managing agents was a payment made with a view to save business expenditure in the relevant accounting year as well as for a few more years. It was not made for acquiring any enduring benefit or income-yielding asset.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment directly linked to avoiding revenue liabilities under wholly and exclusively for business test and commercial expediency.

holdings.text: We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming lower courts via application of revenue vs capital distinction, precedents like Noble, Anglo-Persian, no enduring benefit, and commercial expediency on facts.

precedents.citation: B. IV. Noble Limited v. Mitchell, 1  11 Tax Cas 372

anchor.surface_text: B. IV. Noble Limited v. Mitchell, 1  in the ordinary case a payment to get rid of a servant when it is number expedient to keep him in the interest of trade would be a deductible expenditure. A payment made to remove the possibility of a recurring disadvantage cannot be companysidered as a payment made to acquire an enduring advantage.

precedents.cited_proposition: payment to get rid of a servant when it is not expedient to keep him in the interest of trade would be a deductible expenditure; a payment made to remove the possibility of a recurring disadvantage cannot be considered as a payment made to acquire an enduring advantage
precedents.cited_holding: the payment of pound 19,200 made to retiring Director was an admissible deduction in arriving at profits for income-tax purposes

precedents.citation: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.  1  10 T.C. P. 192

anchor.surface_text: relied on the observations of Lord Chancellor in Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.  1  to the effect a sum of money expended, number of necessity and with a view to a direct and immediate benefit to the trade, but voluntarily and on the grounds of companymercial expediency, and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business, may yet be expanded wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the trade.

precedents.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: a sum of money expended, not of necessity and with a view to a direct and immediate benefit to the trade, but voluntarily and on the grounds of commercial expediency, and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business, may yet be expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the trade

precedents.citation: Anglo Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale.  2  16 Tax Cas 253

anchor.surface_text: The next case which may be usefully referred is the decision in Anglo Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale.  2   Therein the assessee companypany by agreement made in 1910 and 1914 had appointed another limited companypany as its agents in Persia and the East for a period of years, upon the terms  inter alia  that the agents should be remunerated by companymission at specified rates.

precedents.case_name: Anglo Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale
precedents.cited_proposition: payment to cancel onerous agency contract involving future commission payments is admissible deduction as revenue expenditure, not capital merely because it secures enduring benefit by getting rid of onerous contract
precedents.cited_holding: the payment of pound 300,000 to agents was an admissible deduction for income-tax and Corporation Profits Tax

precedents.citation: C. Scammell and Nephew Ltd. v. Rowles,  1  1940 I.T.R. Suppl 41

anchor.surface_text: In C. Scammell and Nephew Ltd. v. Rowles,  1  the Court of Appeal held that the expenditure incurred for the termination of a trading relationship in order to avoid losses occurring in the future through that relationship, wheth er pecuniary losses or companymercial inconveniences, is just as much for the purposes of the trade as the making or the carrying into effect of a trading agreement.

precedents.case_name: C. Scammell and Nephew Ltd. v. Rowles
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure incurred for the termination of a trading relationship in order to avoid losses occurring in the future through that relationship, whether pecuniary losses or commercial inconveniences, is just as much for the purposes of the trade as the making or carrying into effect of a trading agreement

precedents.citation: Anglo-Persian Oil Co.  India  Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax.  2  1933 vol. I, I.T.R. 129

anchor.surface_text: The case which can be said to be the nearest to the facts of the present case decided by any Indian companyrt is that decided by the Calcutta High Court in Anglo-Persian Oil Co.  India  Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax.  2  Therein money was paid by an oil companypany in a lump sum as companypensation for loss of agency whereby the companypany relieved itself of future annual payments of companymission chargeable to revenue account.

precedents.case_name: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. (India) Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: lump sum compensation paid for termination of agency, relieving the company of future annual commission payments chargeable to revenue account, is allowable as revenue expenditure; principle that capital receipt spells capital expenditure or vice versa is not necessarily sound
precedents.cited_holding: the money paid as compensation was allowable as proper deduction from the business profits

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

outcome.relief_summary: Payment of Rs. 2,50,000/- for termination of managing agency is allowable deduction as revenue expenditure

anchor.surface_text: From the facts found,- it is clear that the managing agency was terminated on business considerations and as a matter of commercial expediency. There is no basis for holding that by terminating the managing agency the Company acquired any enduring benefit ,or any income yielding asset.
We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: There is no basis for holding that by terminating the managing agency. the Company acquired any enduring benefit ,or any income yielding asset. It is true that by terminating the services of the managing agents, the Company not only saved the expense that it would have had to incur in the relevant previous year but also for few more years to come.
We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: It will not be correct to say that by avoiding certain business expenditure, the Company can be said to have acquired enduring benefits or acquired any income yielding asset. To quote the illustration given by Rowlatt J. in B. W. Noble Limited v. Mitchell, in the ordinary case a payment to get rid of a servant when it is not expedient to keep him in the interest of trade would be a deductible expenditure.
We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the facts set out earlier that the compensation paid for termination of the services of the managing agents was a payment made with a view to save business expenditure in the relevant accounting year as well as for a few more years. It was not made for acquiring any enduring benefit or income-yielding asset.
We agree with the High Court that the Tribunal was right in its conclusion that the expenditure in question was a revenue expenditure.
